comment._content:
All the little kids who turned up that day for the big dipper were disappointed!

What a great photo! 

A true Meccano set! Shipped from England and assembled right there.

comment.author: 28304000@N00
comment._content: The big dipper was still 5 years away.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] I'm still in awe of the size of the enterprise and the audacity of the decision to build the bridge.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
Agree with that! Considering that there was no comparative infrastructure to link it to back then.

The experience of seeing the "monster" rise from nowhere must have been much like the Eiffel tower for Parisians earlier.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Hey albert3801, don't tell them that, they'll really be devastated! ;-)

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: In response to Highranger. Bradfield of course actually foresaw the required infrastructure, the City railway was part of it, unfortunately Macquarie Street was short sighted.  The emasculated Sydney underground, and lack of Warringah railway are testimomy to that.

comment._content: my mum watched it come together, and she was one of the thousands who walked across it at the opening

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gramarye] I like your mother's photos of the bridge just before the arch was joined.  There must have been massive strain on all the extra cables holding the arches and cranes up.
